description.text:
Chess is awesome. Lasers are awesome. It follows that laser chess is even more awesome.
There are many versions of laser chess, this one is inspired by Khet 2.0.
I plan to make an entirely laser cut version using refraction and internal reflection in the near future.

Build Instructions
(1) For both sides, print:
  • 1x King
  • 1x Laser
  • 2x Guards
  • 2x two sided ("scarabs")
  • 7x one sided ("pyramids")
    (2) Add reflective surfaces to one/two-sided (pyramids & scarabs). Tin foil didn't work for me so I used thin sheets of polished metal.
    (3) Signify immune side of guard
    (4) Decorate king
    (5) Install laser diode, switch, battery to laser piece
    (6) Enjoy!
    • Board Build Instructions (optional)
    (1) Laser cut both pieces
    (2) Glue them together Normal Rules
    (1) All pieces move like a king in regular chess, or alternatively rotate by ninety degrees, wit the exceptions:
  • Laser piece can only rotate
  • two-sided mirror pieces can forcefully swap places with an adjacent single-sided or guard piece (this is to avoid stalemates)
    (2) At the end of a players turn, they must fire their laser
    (3) A piece hit on a non-mirrored or otherwise immune (in the case of a guard) side is destroyed.
    (4) See picture for recommended staring layout
    • Ideas for Alternative Rules
    (1) Have both players move simultaneously by writing their move on paper
    (2) Introduce a half-silvered mirror.
    (3) Add pieces that behave differently at different heights, and pieces that shift the beam up or down.

These are towhooks large and small for launching model aircraft on a bungee launcher.
I use the small one for smaller wings such as a Pinata or the Caipi (about 1kg AUW)
I use the large one for my Chimera. (2-4KG AUW)
They are designed to attach to a key ring, The small one to about a 1" and the large to about a 2" ring.
Be sure to mount these to a structural area of your plane about 2/3rd's the distance from the nose to the CG on the centerline. And rough up the base of these printed parts well so they accept the glue. I use GOOP to glue them to foam. I also like to carve out a square into the foam and sink the printed part into the foam for added strength of the bond.

title: Rhythm Cube Machine V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The idea is to build a percussion machine where you can create customized rhythms. The three different sized blocks provide different pitch when stroked while the twelve holes inside the spinning wheel controls the timing of each strike. There are more than 1700 possible combinations.
The hole design is made from 9 pieces, and fits in a 10x10x10cm box, what made the challenge much harder

title: aluminium y drivetrain for prusa i3 - template

description.text:
i3 y motor drivetrain is very weak part when made out of plastic -  it bends and it melts when motor overheats. 
At the same time there is plenty of aluminium left out of basic frame cutting for reuse, and one can make aluminium motor holder in very short time even using ordinary cordless drill , especially if one does have printed template. 
you can use my files to print the template - they are designed for 10mm smooth rods, with 10mm threaded rods version of i3. and ofcourse it's easy to make any other template using scad sources.

title: Ultimaker 2 Clone  + Ramps 1.4 = Cheap and Cheerful!

description.text:
Ver1.01 Upgrades!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1644564
For geared extruder and better XY block Ver1.02 Upgrades!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1829658
To mount your printer on a mobile platform (with IKEA Trofast kids storage frame) This is a tribute to the Ultimaker 2 tribute clone. Thumbs up for the guy who created that one (^_^)b The main motivation is cost £$, this is a decent 3D Printer for the 99%. The cost reduction is a factor of 4 (UM 2 retail for £1,700 in UK!), using only Open Source Hardware/Software, it cost in total about £350 (~US$530). Print volume is comparable at 205x205x213mm (XYZ), print quality is demonstrated to match Ultimaker 2, print speed is similar. Using original UM2 heatbed, it is capable of 110C @28V Full Documentation here:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1JPuVnPbgEVJBtv9Qa7PbaXDT3Li_uc_8paK1C8bIbXs/edit?usp=sharing Bill of Material for this build:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1U4j3FyiDujAYAjnLLlz5OU1p1zNjxOUnA1WLZx2qzLQ/edit?usp=sharing RAMPS 1.4 + Marlin Firmware for this build:
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B8KH9HafldNiQktWeTRscDRDb2s/view?usp=sharing All STL (Including those not design by me - Full attribution provided in documentation) :
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B8KH9HafldNibEJZSFUxVk5IMTQ/view?usp=sharing Uploading STL I've designed or remixed Enjoy! Comments!

a very easy to print quadcopter. you'll need:
  • aluminium profile 10x10mm (I used 2x 500mm length)
  • KK2.0 flight controller
  • Q Brain 4 x 20A Brushless Quadcopter ESC 2-4S 3A SBEC
  • 4x Turnigy 1100KV Brushless Motors
  • NIMH/LiPo Battery
  • 4 Channel Sender/Reciever
    • You will have to use araldite or similar glue to glue in the aluminium profiles into the base and motor mount. print with 0.8mm wall thickness, 40% infill:
    2x base
    4x motormount
    1x controller
    1x batteryholder_a
    1x batteryholder_b
    2x foot_30mm
    2x foot_40mm Assembly as shown in build_complete.stl This is a work in progress... Detailed infos and additional parts follow... (though it is flyable as it is!) Update 1:
    I just added a prototype of the landing gear. the battery holder is right now fit for a 8 cell nimh battery but will soon be replaced by a lipo pack... Update 2:
    I added build_complete as a 3d build instruction (not meant for printing) Update 3:
    I wasn't happy with the motor mounts and feet so I redesigned them. Tested the quadracopter today and the flight was great! I'm quite happy with the current design but I'm waiting for my LiPo battery to arrive... The redesign also results in having to print less items.

title: Emergency Stop button for Printrbot Play

description.text:
This is an emergency stop button for my PrintrBot play. It screws into the four screws holes on the bottom right hand part of the printer, using the existing screws. Using a "Push to break" switch on Amazon, and some cables you can run the negative wire through the switch and back to the Printrbot, which gives you a nice "Emergency Stop" button. When the button is pressed, the Printrbot loses power and cannot continue. Warning: You can break your printer, PSU and other things if you screw up the wiring. Be sure you know what you're doing before you attempt this. All information here is "as is" and simply documents what I've done. I cannot and will not be held liable for any breakages of any sort because you tried to follow what I've done. This is useful if you notice something disastrous happening, such as the hot end slamming into the print bed and you need to stop the printer immediately, and not when Octoprint (or whatever you're using) stops sending instructions to the printer and it's buffer clears. This will stop the printer dead, whatever it's doing. Not in a minute or a few seconds, it will stop immediately. It'll have no choice; it has no power. I've been running the Play off a ATX PSU, this means my handy inline 12v switch is no good anymore, plus I can now power my Octoprint Raspberry Pi and some sexy LED lights all from the PSU. However, killing the power to the Raspberry Pi suddenly is probably a bad idea for the longevity of it. So this was an easy way of killing power to the Play without turning off anything else. Note: This WILL NOT work with the Heated Bed upgrade, as this needs to connect to the PCI-E connector coming from the PSU, and the switch cannot break the several connections coming from the PCI-E connector. You cannot power the play from the regular 12v supply as I've done here and power the heated bed; it simply won't work and will probably damage the wiring and cause fire. I've wired in a ATX power supply, using a Molex extension cable (I don't mind cutting up a cheap extension cable, but I want to leave the PSU itself as is) and some standard plugs. All parts brought from Amazon. Links are all below. I'm still using the connector through the side to power the Play, and not powering from the PCI-E connector. I couldn't get the Play to power from the Molex connector and heat the bed at the same time. BE AWARE - This fits MY printrbot play. The four screws are NOT uniform in their location, they differ slightly on each corner. This made measuring them a pain in the ass and I have a feeling the screw holes are made in a "close enough to what we want" fashion by Printrbot. You may have to modify the model a little to make it fit YOUR Play. I have no idea how uniform each batch of Plays are, or even if they are different within each batch. The STL file includes both the lid and the base. Use Cura's "Split Objects" feature, and delete one of the models so you only print one at a time, otherwise it won't fit. Print the lid (part with text on) the correct way around, using supports, for the best finish. The base needs no supports. I printed both parts with brims to prevent warping. You'll need to sand down the inside of the lid to make it fit - It's a tight fit. If you're using thicker cables than I am, you may need to file down the little slot in the lid as well. Links for the bits I've used on Amazon (These are affiliate links, buying through these will get me a small amount of commission which I'll probably use to buy more filament with!):
PSU: Corsair CP-9020096-UK VS Series VS450 ATX/EPS 80 PLUS 450W Power Supply Unit, UK
Small Extension lead for PSU's Molex connectors: StarTech.com LP4 to 2x LP4 Power Y Splitter Cable M/F
Push to break switch: Red Square On(Off) Momentary Push to Break Switch SPST
Power connector to go into the side of the Play: BW 10 Pcs 5.5mm x 2.1mm DC Power Cable Male Connector Plug for CCTV Camera

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes
Sand down the inner part of the lid, where it will meet the base. The fit is very tight, and you'll need to sand it down a little before it fits.

description.text:
This Thinkfun Maker Studio expansion set is designed to add energy to the existing sets: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:872140
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:871201 and
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:871205 Add LED lights to your build and use your imagination! Use the motor coupling and mount to add a small motor to your creation. You can also try to generate your own electricity by running the motor backwards to power the lights without batteries. Discover gear ratios with the existing sets and electrical principals with this expansion.
5mm LED's, alligator clips, (2xAA or AAA) batteries and a DC motor will need to be obtained. The 3 printable items in this expansion are:
An LED bezel clip - To mount an LED into a connector hole or through another part of a build like the box in the racecar I made.
A motor coupling - To attach the motor shaft to a gear or connector. Here is the coupling used to connect the motor to the propeller https://youtu.be/KWbt5GXzB0o
A motor mount - To attach the rear of the motor to a hub cap or into a connector. The wiring of the LED's can be tricky. A resistor is recommended. For general purposes a 1kΩ resistor should be fine. See here http://ledcalc.com/ to determine the resistor you need for your chosen LED as well as a wiring diagram.
I used blue LED's with 2xAAA batteries (total 3V) and 1000 Ω (1kΩ) resistors. Hide the wiring inside your build. You may need to construct gearing to greatly increase the speed to the generator (motor) if you want to power the LED's. In my attempts I was not able to generate enough voltage. Maybe a geared or low speed motor would help. The reduction gear in the photo is ratio 16:1 using the large and small gears. Have fun!

Print the LED bezel as slow as possible. I used 30mm/s

The LED bezel has a small barb to hold in onto a connector. It required some force to press it into the hole (and to remove). I had a 2mm shaft motor which needed heating to press the shaft into the coupling.
Adjust the motor shaft diameter to fit the shaft of your motor. Here is the tinkercad file for the coupling to make your own changes.
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jTdhLKAdt1O-maker-studio-motor-coupling Regarding the motor mount. I'm sure this wont fit all motors. I would suggest a heat gun to soften the print and fit the motor. It will be good to glue them together being careful to make sure the shaft is free spinning.

I wanted to create a set that could be used with all of the existing Maker Studio set and so I though of adding lights. The lights can be used as headlights on vehicles or anything else your imagination leads you to.
Although battery operated was the easy option I also wanted the option to be free of batteries. In our world of growing renewable energy it might be nice to incorporate a small generator to power the light instead. This could open the door to new builds like windmills, turbines, reduction and increasing gearboxes.
So far the attempts with the small motor I had were not successful. They usually have a very high speed and need a really big speed increasing gear ratio. I would suggest looking for a 3V motor having a low speed or it's own reduction gears.

author: Dutch_Engineer

description.text: I liked the idea of watsdesign's business card holder, but when I printed it, the 0.5mm-thick sides were too thin; they warped and buckled a bit.  So I remixed it by simply thickening all the sides to 1.0mm.  I also found it was just a little too small to fit my cards, so I expanded it 1mm.  Finally, for a little flourish, I added a few rounded corners.

Doesn't need support or anything else, though I did use a brim since it has a fairly small amount of surface area on the print bed.  Be careful removing it from the print bed though; since the bottom is so thin, it can be easy (depending on print quality) to break off the bottom in the process.

title: JiGuan TC 50W Box Mod Box Battery

description.text:
This box battery work with JiGuan TC 50w board.
I take the board here for 18$: https://www.fasttech.com/p/3717200
In the board i cut the bluetooth push button and the bluetooth antenna. To mount this mod u need:
  • a 510 connector (Fat Daddy, for example);
  • 4 magnets 3x2;
  • 4 magnets 3x1;
  • 8 magnets 4x1;
  • positive contact and negative spring.
    • I printed the body and the door in vertical with support using 150 micron but u can use 200 micron too.
    If u print PLA in vertical i suggest the raft, especially for the door (!). There are 3 version of body with 3 different connector hole (10, 12 and 13 mm): Fatdaddy is 10 mm. U can find some extra photos here:
    http://www.esigblog.com/jiguan-tc-50w-box-battery-stampante-3d

2015.12.10 I've just updated the STLs, as some Slicing software was starting the print from the inside out.... When slicing in MakerBot set the number of Shells to 300.
If using Slic3r, then set the Perimeters to 300' (Update message:- I've just uploaded a 190mm x 120mm version for smaller beds. The size isn't important, other than you need it to fit on your Work Platform (Bed)). The original was 210mm x 140mm. If you have a need for a smaller version, please msg me and I'll add one for you). This is a simple STL that just has your printer drawing a square on the Print Bed. How to Use:-
1) Set your Bed level by moving the Extruder above the four adjusting screws, and gapping with paper. So you can just feel some light resistance.
2) Slice the attached STL and print the file (don't worry you won't be printing it ALL unless your very slow at setting up the table) preferably using a Coloured filament (eg Black is great). Remember to set the Shells/Perimeters to 300.....
3) Watch the print taking shape. If the print is transparent, then the Table/Nozzle gap is to small, so tighten up the screws. If the print is highly coloured (A solid Colour), then the Nozzle/Table gap is to big.
4) As the Print head moves around the table, tweek the adjusting screws until the print just
starts to pick up colour all over the Bed, and the feeder doesn't skip. That's your bed really nice and level now... :)

description.text:
Use about 0,5G of plastic
Print time: 3 min
Need a working printer
Need infil, works fine with 20% and fast honeycomb
Size: 10x10x5mm, hollow center with 6x6x3 It works testing a adehesion test, done by the Z axis, add one in each corner of the bed
(please keep in mind that kapton tape, hairspray and all those thing wont work if your nozze is too high from the bed, with this test you can see if it is ok,

First of all, make sure the nozzle is ALMOST touching the bed, (use a paper under it, if it can move, not too hard, but not free, its perfect),
-MAKE SURE ALL THE CORNERS ARE LEVELED! and you have something flat on the top (like a glass or metal!, pcb is NOT flat!)
-add one at each corner of the bed
-Print them with 0,2 layer high - noozle of 0,4 (of course can be printed with others)

CAME OUT TOO EASY - DID NOT STICK ON THE BED
-If it did not "glued" on the bed You need to bring your Z endstop a bit down. half a milimeter (remember the paper on the previous step?) PLASTIC DID NOT CAME OUT OF THE EXTRUDER
-First of all. move the Z axis up, heat it up, and let some plastic go down (the driver probably damaged the filament) 1cm of plastic is ok.
-You need to find the "origin offset" of your slicer, and add on the z axis
I usually change it from .2mm to .2mm. but first try add 0,3mm PLASTIC HAD DIFFICULT TO CAME OUT

add 0,2mm to the start height
and go on, adding 0,1 until you have a perfect adehesion for you.

remember, too low is BAD, it will be hard to remove it from the bed, and may damage the noozle!, Now we will check the temperature, If it was too high, you will see deformation on the corners. if is too low, layers will "unglue" one of other.
Try changing 5ºC each test! And ALWAYS remember!, to have decent print quality, you will need a fan to cool the wires. i use one both for the hotend body and the piece, and im having awesome printings when i turned the fan to remove the air from the piece. (when it was reversed, i had problems with low adehesion and warping)

author: WanderingShepherd

description.text:
Inside Earth is an exploded view of the different layers of earth. 3/4 of the earth are to be glued together as shown in the pictures while the remaining 1/4 of the earth is to remain as loose parts so that it can be put together and taken apart for easy explanation and enjoyment. This is meant to teach K-12 students the different layers of this lovely planet we live on. The pieces are separate to allow printing them in different colors and/or materials to help show the contrast between the layers. Due to the spherical design and the orientation of the pieces the earth should be printable with little to no supports. If printing parts as pre arranged groups (painting):
Print:
  • Earth grouped parts1.stl (x1)
  • Earth grouped parts2.stl (x1)
  • Earth Core.stl (x1)
    • If printing parts separately (different materials / painting):
    Print:
  • Crust.stl (x2)
  • Crust_labled.stl (x2)
  • Mantle.stl (x2)
  • Mantle_labled.stl (x2)
  • Outer_Core.stl (x2)
  • Outer_Core_labled.stl (x2)
  • Earth Core.stl (x1)

Printer:

BIO KOSSEL ( KosselXL remix )

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

20%

Notes: Recommend printing with a skirt that is touching the pieces and is at least 5-10 loops to help adhesion to the bed since the majority of each part does not touch the bed.

Finishing Use your preference of glue (I use 2 part epoxy but any glue designed for plastic will work and some might be much better for use around children) to glue 3/4 of the earth together (the parts are mostly interchangeable as long as all text faces outward and the core is in the center. IMPORTANT make sure you glue the pieces around the core, if you do not put the core in the center before gluing it WILL NOT FIT! If you are painting the earth vice printing in different materials I recommend painting each piece prior to gluing to ensure clean even edges.

title: Just right light for Lulzbot Mini

description.text: Aziz light! Luvs me da Mini but it doesn't come with lights. The cheap LED flashlights from Lowes or Home Depot get the job done but here's a better, more permanent solution to the problem. For me, 24" of LED strip lights front and back is massive overkill. Six warm analog LEDs in front yields a little over 40 foot-candles at the bed and that seems reasonable. This clip is designed to snug fit the top frame without drilling holes or additional hardware and, angles the LED strip towards the bed/extruder so you get the light just where you need it and nowhere else. I used two segments of this adhesive backed strip (about 120mA @ 12VDC) and printed in black so it blends in. https://www.adafruit.com/products/357 If your strip is shorter or longer just scale the Z-axis.

These are simple connectors for building your own Korean fighting kite. My son needed to build one for his project on Asia so I designed and printed out corner connectors, t-connectors, and a central connector with my Cupcake. I went with this design for our kite: http://www.kiteplans.org/planos/coreen/coreen.html You will need to use Google Translate to translate the page from French to English. One thing that I did was up-scale the dimensions of the kit a bit so that they're slightly larger than the metric-to-english conversion on the above design. There are similar designs on http://www.kiteplans.org/pln_1564/ as well.

Print out the kite-connectors-plate.stl (prints a spare corner and t-connector for you). It'll just fit on a Makerbot build platform. If you want to print each part separately (or need a spare) you'll need to print 1 kite-center-connector.stl, 4 kit-corner.stl, and 4 kite-t-connector.stl. You will also need enough 1/8" dowel rod for the following: 3 - 13" lengths (horizontal supports)
3 - 18" lengths (vertical supports)
2 - 22" lengths (diagonal supports) I just used an exacto knife to cut the dowel rod to length. Also the holes were a bit tight (which I liked for the corner pieces but not so much for the T-connectors). I drilled out the corner holes and the short vertical in the t-connector with a 1/8" bit to make the dowel rod slip in easier. I then used a 9/64" bit to ream out the horizontal holes in the t-connector and in the center connector holes so that it went all the way through so that the dowel rod would slide through easily. Next, assemble it per the attached photo. Hot glue the corners and leave the center connector and the horizontal through-hole in the t-connectors unglued so that the kite can flex a bit. We then cut a piece of thin white fabric ~2" wider and taller than the kite frame, decorated it, and then hot glued it around the perimeter of the frame. We then attached the kite string per the attached image. I'll upload an image of the finished kite once we've completed it.

title: Radial print cooling fans for a CoreXY printer

description.text:
I recently built this CoreXY printer - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1003119 - and decided that I wanted to mount a pair of 50mm radial fans for print cooling, rather than the original single ducted fan (I had modified the X carriage and the original one wouldn't fit). I aimed for simplicity as far as possible; the parts are exactly the same on each side, and use very little plastic. Update: 12/02/2016
I found that these 2 fans are too efficient for the poor hot-end, to the point where they would chill the hot-end when running at anywhere over 50%. Because of this I designed an air duct that pointed down by about 45 degrees; the fans still cool the extruded plastic but most of the air misses the hot-end nozzle block, which stays at the set temperature. Update: 8/03/2016
Oops! The downward-pointing ducts I recently posted were the ones for the Prusa i3 cooling fans - I have just posted the correct ones...

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes: The fan and X carriage mounts are printed in PLA - I got better-quality results by laying the fan mount on its side before slicing. Printing it in the obvious way (fan side down, post upwards) seemed to leave the top post very weak - but that may be my printing technique! The nozzles are printed in ABS as each one lives so close to the hot end - no support required as they are printed with its large open end flat on the bed. I recommend printing 2 at the same time so that neither gets overheated. Note that the nozzles have a slight offset as the fans don't quite point at the hot-end nozzle - but these fans produce so much airflow that any misalignment is irrelevant.

No special requirements after printing - tidy up the pieces, use a 4mm drill bit to make sure that the holes are clear, screw the small bracket to the underside of the X carriage, screw on the fan bracket, then connect the 2 together.
I used a dab of glue to hold the nozzles in the fan outlets - yours may fit firmly enough not to need the glue.
Once mounted, move the carriage slowly until you are sure that the fans do not collide with anything.

I primarily use the disappearing purple glue sticks to help with bed adhesion. So I needed a better way to store my glue sticks than just in the package in a drawer. So I looked around and found the "Parametric Cylindrical Battery Dispenser" by Justblair, and saw it would be perfect to remix and make a little bigger to fit the glue stick dimensions. I also extended the model in the middle so I could glue the two halves together.
I also wanted a way to separately store the current glue stick I am using from the reserves, so I modeled two additional pieces so I could have a side holster for the in-use glue stick.
I printed the two halves as one print, and then printed the top and bottom for the holster as another print. I included several of the .stl files so you can print them all as one, or any of the individual pieces. Or however you want.
This is my first remix and post of a design, so hopefully you enjoy it. I appreciate any and all feedback. Thanks.

title: Hot and Cold Cubes Positive and Negative Counters

description.text: Learning addition and subtraction of positive and negative numbers can be a challenge to many students. Traditionally, students model using a number line and arrows indicating magnitude and direction, however, this representation has its short comings. An alternative approach is to model with positive and negative counters. A hook activity for this is using a story called Chef's Cubes, by Interactive Mathematics (http://mathimp.org/), which relates traditional counters to hot and cold cubes used to control the temperature of a magical soup. I have had great success in using this hook activity but I do not have any manipulative for students to get their hands on - they are limited to drawing + or - signs on their paper. This model is to overcome that and get the cubes in their hands so they can make a richer connection between the story and how to effectively model addition and subtraction of positive and negative numbers through the use of hot and cold cubes.

Objectives: Students are expected to make their own hot and cold cubes to use as manipulatives in modeling addition and subtraction of positive and negative integers. This can be expanded upon to model multiplication and division of positive and negative numbers as well. Audiences: Grade 6 and 7 mathematics students. Preparation Students should already know the four basic operations with positive integers. Steps Begin with reading the Chef's Cubes story (available online: Link) Then have students print their own cubes to use - if this is a linked learning or STEM/Maker class, have them design and print their own customized versions of the cubes Once they have a set of cubes, they can then progress through the operations with positive and negative integers. Begin with demonstrating what a hot cold and a cold cube would be equal to when added: 1 + (-1) = 0. This concept of a zero-pair is essential for modeling with cubes. Then move onto having them add in zero pairs of cubes (one hot and one cold) so they can resolve simple situations For example: 5 - 8 = - 3. This would start with 5 hot cubes, then since we are removing a larger number than we started with, we have to add 3 zero pairs. documentation and lesson plans can be found on modeling with positive and negative counters. Results Through the use of tangible cubes, students show an increased connection and understanding to the concept of addition and subtraction of positive and negative integers.

title: Replacement Parts for Sinclair ZX Spectrum+

description.text:
Varias piezas de recambio para el Sinclair Spectrum Plus:
  • Tecla normal.
  • Tecla Ancha, break, delete, extended mode.
  • Patas y pieza de soporte de las patas.
    • Las teclas no tienen un acabado muy bueno, las medidas son correctas, y funcionan aceptablemente.
    Las patas han sido creadas de cero, ya que no tenia el original, y probablemente no sean iguales, aunque funcionalmente me gusta el resultado. Se incluye el archivo fuente por si alguien quiere hacer alguna otra tecla o modificar esas. Several replacement parts for Sinclair Spectrum Plus microcomputer:
  • Normal Key
  • Big Key, break, delete, extended mode.
  • Legs and support for the legs.
    • They keys have not good finish, but measures are correct and work great.
    The legs are designed without original measures, probably not match the original, but I like the end result. Source File is included if someone want to modify or create other keys.

Para las teclas puede ser necesario aumentar el agujero para la pieza blanca utilizando una pieza de metal caliente.
Para las patas, pegue una pieza de fieltro en la tapa superior del spectrum, para que no lo dañe y soporte bien.
Las patas tienen un agujero para una pieza de goma o silicona de 12mm de diametro.
For the keys is possible to need to enlarge the hole for the white pieze using a hot metal or something similar.
I glue a piece of course fabric in the top cover to support the legs support.
There is a hole in the leg for a piece of silicone of 12mm diameter.
Designed with Trimble Sketchup

This Truck Construction Kit is an expansion pack to the "ThinkFun Maker Studio original set".
It's rather simple to assemble the truck by using the manual.
An advantage of this expansion pack is, that you can make some parts of cardboard or, if you want to, you can print them too. If you want to use cardboard, there are several templates in the manual to help you cutting the right size of the parts.
A detailed description and instruction of all the parts and how to assemble the truck is included in the manual (pdf file).
All parts from this expansion pack fit in a total build volume of 10 x 10 x 12,5cm (L x W x H).

You can vary the amount of the infill to in- or decrease the stability of the plates.
The resolution can be varied individually. E.g. the plates don't need the same high resolution as the connector parts. For those who want to force an all-in-one print of this expansion pack I've added two STL files, one with all parts and one without the roof and the motor plates, in case you use cardboard. The total build volume is 10 x 10 x 12,5cm (L x W x H). For an all-in-one print supports are needed.
I don't recommend printing all-in-one because this could lead to a loss of quality and all parts are printed in the same color.
It is better to print e.g. all the connector parts together and the plates seperate and I recommend to use the provided single STL files of the parts.

Inspired by Theo Jansen's Strandbeests. After making the Glowstrand (http://www.coolkidsrobots.com/robot/glowstrand), I decided that I wanted to design something that was all mine... and with a big change, Mid Outboard Motors, using some cheaper more available gear motors. I got the motors from IC Station, but they are available in many stores. They must have the dual output shafts for this design. Deca is very fast, its going to need some excellent sensors and processing, I'm using a Parallax Propeller Quickstart board and a L9110S DC/Stepper Motor Driver Board for motor control. It also has eight 4 x 10 x 4mm ball bearings for the big gears. I used short pieces of filament for pins on all the leg joints, carefully melted over the ends to make them stay put. The frames are held together with four 125mm long pieces of m4 threaded rod, and a bunch of nuts and the 8mm and 11mm spacers. I used nylon nuts mostly. For the big gears, I used two 53mm long pieces of m4 threaded rod as axles, with m4 locking nuts. For the crank pins I used m4 nylon screws. You will need to drill and tap the holes in the gears. You will also need to clean up all the 4mm and 1.8mm holes in each part.
You can see more here http://www.coolkidsrobots.com/robot/deca-son-glowstrand 12/10/15, updated the head with better path for wiring and sunk servo horn screw heads. 12/12/15 Added spacers for running motor power through the threaded rods and making a cleaner look (Connector_11x4mmSpacer.stl). You will need to find some set screws and drill and tap as appropriate. Then tin the ends of the wires before inserting and clamping them. 12/13/15 Added a mount for boards 12/20/15 I made a servo head for a RadioShack Ultrasonic Range Sensor and a Sharp IR GP2Y0A21YK0F Analog Distance Sensor. Recessed mounting holes for 9g servo horn, also has nice wire path. Also posted here:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1213658

BOM Ankle.stl - Print 8 of these and 8 that are mirrored
thigh3D.stl - Print 8 of these and 8 that are mirrored
Each half (mirrored pairs) to be pinned together with short pieces of filament and glued with super glue, you will need to ream out the pin holes with a 1.8mm drillbit dogbone3.stl- Print 8 of these and 8 that are mirrored
Use small allen wrenches in the pivot holes to align and glue these halves together LongRod3D.stl - Print 8 of these MidRod3d_x.stl - Print 8 of these ShortRod3d.stl - Print 8 of these Pinion4.2-1.stl - Print 4 of these Spur Gear4.2-1.stl - Print 4 of these Shoe.stl - Print 8 of these OuterFrame.stl - Print 2 of these and 2 that are mirrored bodySide.stl - Print 1 of these and 1 mirrored bodyTop.stl - Print 1 of these 11x4mmSpacer.stl - Print 6 of these - or 2, see Connector_11x4mmSpacer.stl Connector_11x4mmSpacer.stl - Optional - print 4 - use for hiding wiring by using threaded rods for power to motors 8mmSpacer.stl - Print 8 of these DecaServoHeadv3.stl - Print 1 - will fit HC-sr04 sensor (16mm transducers 25.4mm apart) DecaServoHeadBackv3.stl - Print 1 EndBar.stl - Print 2 All the inner pivot points are 1.8mm will need to be reamed out with a 1.8mm drillbit and then when assembled use short pieces of 1.75mm filament as pins, carefully melt the ends to make them stay put.
All the 4mm pivot pints will also need to be reamed out with a 4mm drillbit.
I used a lot of nylon nuts and some metal and locknuts.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3qgomT6isZW

This is a playful as well as an informative toy which teaches children about energy in forms of storage and what happens when you release that stored energy in different ways.
Throwbot 'A' demostrates elastic potentential energy through a rubber band, whereas thowbot 'B' demonstrates kinetic and potential energy through a spiral torsional spring.
Explore how far you want your object to reach, get creative and become smarter!! The exciting part about the toy is that the child could actually explore the projectile of the object ejected through the catapult by trying in various weights, twisting the spring harder to create more kinetic energy in the catapult for a heavier weight. Experimenting with the rubber band length to understand potential energy in terms of the position of the catapult. Two kids having the same set could play together and explore the lengths of this toy further by getting creative with their minds. This toy creates curiosity in the child about how energy relates to its environmental features. It can be expanded and attached to a box or even to one of the thingiverse car expansion sets to give it a movement. This is the easiest way for a child to play and learn about the basics of energy storage.

throbot with spring throwbot with rubberband

I decided to build a catapult, since it would provide a great learning curve for children to understand the concept of stored energy and its reaction on an object when the energy is released. To make the toy a little challenging, I made use of demonstrating two kinds of energies. A catapult with elastic potential energy where the energy is stored in the rubber band when stretched or extended, when released it shows its potential to perform a task like throwing an object with a certain force at a certain distance.
The same catapult when attached to a set of coiled springs on either side demonstrates kinetic as well as potential energy. Here, the kinetic energy is stored in the coiled spring when compressed and potential energy acts when the force is released of off the coiled spring.

This is a case for SLR and DSLR lens filters. This one fits a 55mm lens filter.
The walls of this filter holder are thicker then they need to be, but should provide plenty of protection for your lens filters. Scale up or down for different size filers. There is a similar idea around here somewhere uploaded in a CAD file. I am not real comfortable with cad programs, so I created this one using 123D Design. The 123D file is here too. As you can probably see in the photo, I placed a raft under the 1st one that I printer. But it did not need it.
